title: Ticket #2351: Ensure CREAM lease exists before submitting job in gridmanager
description:
When submitting a CREAM job, the CreamJob object in the gridmanager will skip checking the value/validity of the CREAM lease (maintained in the CreamResource object) if CreamLeaseId is set in the job ad. This can lead to the submission failing because the lease isn't registered on the server.

The CreamJob object should always check with the CreamResource about the value of the lease id and its status before attempting to submit. When information about a previous submit attempt is scrubbed from the job ad in GM_CLEAR_REQUEST, CreamLeaseId should be removed.
remarks:
2011-Aug-15 13:32:17 by tannenba:
IIRC, part of this is to deal w/ leveraging the capability of CREAM to share one lease across multiple jobs....

2011-Aug-22 14:30:16 by jfrey:
It appears the bug in this ticket can't occur as described. The CreamLeaseId attribute is never set, so it can never be used in the CreamJob constructor to set leaseId and bypass asking the CreamResource for the id of the lease. #2271 may be causing the behavior observed with this ticket. I'm waiting on Rod Walker to try out the fix for that ticket.

2011-Oct-18 16:47:40 by jfrey:
I found a race condition in CreamResource that would explain this behavior. CreamResource won't hand a lease id to CreamJobs via getLeaseId() until m_sharedLeaseExpiration is set to non-zero. But in UpdateLeases(), m_sharedLeaseExpiration is set to the calculated lease value, then control is returned to daemonCore to let the value be saved in the schedd, then CreamResource talks to the server to register it. While CreamResource is waiting for the value to be saved in the schedd, CreamJob objects may try to submit if daemonCore timers fire at the right time. A new guard variable needs to be added to getLeaseId() so that the lease id is returned only after the initial registration of the lease with the server is complete.

2011-Oct-19 14:14:51 by jfrey:
I've sent a patched gridmanager to Rod Walker for testing.

2011-Dec-01 15:37:47 by jfrey:
This bug can also be triggered by the gridmanager retaining CreamResource objects for several minutes after they have no associated jobs (controlled by GRIDMANAGER_EMPTY_RESOURCE_DELAY). During that time, the CreamResource object won't extend the job lease, as it has no jobs to base the length on.

I saw a case with glideinwms where a problem job would become held immediately after it was released, which occurred once a minute due to the job policy expressions. This prevented the CreamResource object from ever being deleted. But each time it checked on job leases, it had no jobs and so never extended the lease, which eventually expired. After that, any new jobs would fail on submission because the lease was invalid. Setting GRIDMANAGER_EMPTY_RESOURCE_DELAY=5 broke the loop, as the CreamResource object was deleted before the next time the problem job was released.

2011-Dec-05 14:01:32 by jfrey:
I've pushed a patch to V7_6-branch and posted a pre-release binary for Rod Walker, Xin Zhao and Igor Sfiligoi to try: ftp://ftp.cs.wisc.edu/condor/temporary/forrod/2011-12-01/condor_gridmanager

2012-Jan-06 14:32:34 by jfrey:
Rod Walker reports that lease problems have not reoccurred since installing the patched binary.
